study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of mobile neurofeedback training on clinical symptoms, attention abilities, and executive functions in children with ADHD.
results_summary: Both neurofeedback and sham groups showed improvements in attention and response inhibition, with neurofeedback specifically reducing inattention in the visual continuous performance test. No significant between-group differences were found in other performance outcomes.
population_specificity: 74 children with ADHD aged 8-15 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of combining neuromuscular training (NMT) and neurofeedback training (NFT) versus NMT alone in rehabilitating athletes with chronic ankle instability (CAI).
results_summary: NMT+NFT was more effective than NMT alone in improving postural control, ankle proprioception, and reducing anxiety and depression in athletes with CAI, though both interventions showed improvements.
population_specificity: Athletes aged 18-25 years with chronic ankle instability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of mu suppression neurofeedback training on mirror neuron system activation and social skills in healthy neurotypical participants.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant mu suppression in MNS-attributed areas during hand movement observation after NFT, but no significant behavioral improvement in emotional interpretation (RMET accuracy). Response times in RMET were reduced post-training.
population_specificity: 16 healthy neurotypical participants
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to span the duration of 15 sessions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of neurofeedback training on brain function in patients with ischemic hypoxic encephalopathy by monitoring relative α variant scores and optic nerve sheath diameter (ONSD).
results_summary: Neurofeedback training significantly improved brain function, as evidenced by higher ONSD and relative α variant scores, reduced mean power and delta-theta ratio in EEG, and better outcomes in depression and stroke scales compared to controls. Plasma 5-HT and BDNF levels also improved more in the neurofeedback group.
population_specificity: Patients with ischemic hypoxic encephalopathy (Glasgow coma score ≤ 8) admitted to emergency and intensive care.
effective_dosage: Neurofeedback training included visual feedback, auditory feedback, meditation, and relaxation for 14 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review existing evidence on neurofeedback training as a potential treatment for cognitive and clinical symptoms in patients with personality disorders.
results_summary: EEG neurofeedback protocols showed improvements in neuropsychological and behavioral functions, while fMRI-based neurofeedback reported neurophysiological changes and behavioral symptom improvements, though studies were preliminary with high risk of bias.
population_specificity: Patients with personality disorders

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and effects of amygdala-related electrical fingerprint (Amyg-EFP) neurofeedback training in patients with borderline personality disorder (BPD) alongside standard dialectical behavior therapy (DBT).
results_summary: Study 1 confirmed the relevance of Amyg-EFP in emotion-related brain circuits. Study 2 showed Amyg-EFP modulation with neurofeedback training, though technical issues with reversed feedback limited interpretability.
population_specificity: Female individuals with borderline personality disorder (BPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term neurofeedback training during the acute stroke phase could enhance prefrontal activity and improve working memory.
results_summary: Neurofeedback training prevented a decline in spatial working memory performance in patients with higher task-related right prefrontal activity, though efficacy was not linked to clinical background factors like Fugl-Meyer Assessment scores or time since stroke.
population_specificity: 30 patients with acute stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of three neurofeedback protocols (enhanced SMR at Cz, suppressed alpha at Fz, and suppressed mu at Cz) on motor learning in novice golfers.
results_summary: Neurofeedback groups outperformed the sham group in short-term retention, with SMR and alpha groups maintaining better performance in long-term retention. The study also found significant variations in brain wave amplitudes corresponding to the neurofeedback interventions.
population_specificity: 64 novice golfers (32 females; mean age = 22.31 ± 2.25 years).
effective_dosage: 20-minute neurofeedback training per session, 3 sessions per week for two weeks.

study_goal: To determine if in situ neurofeedback training improves sustained attention in the general student population and whether these gains enhance work habits and learning skills.
results_summary: Classroom-based neurofeedback was found to be effective in building sustained attention and improving observable work habits and learning behaviors, such as planning and organization. The study suggests neurofeedback may have broader applications beyond ADHD treatment.
population_specificity: General student population

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of infra-low frequency neurofeedback training (ILF-NFT) on symptomatology in an eight-year-old patient with Dravet syndrome.
results_summary: ILF-NFT improved the patient's sleep disturbance, significantly reduced seizure frequency and severity, and reversed neurodevelopmental decline, with positive development in intellectual and motor skills. No significant medication changes were made during the study period.
population_specificity: An eight-year-old patient with Dravet syndrome, a rare and highly disabling form of epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether home-based neurofeedback training without remote monitoring could effectively enable healthy individuals to modulate their EEG activity.
results_summary: Participants were unable to modulate their brain activity as intended during home-based neurofeedback training, and a significant portion (21 out of 38) were excluded due to technical issues or non-compliance, highlighting challenges in unsupervised settings. The study suggests that expert interaction and remote supervision may be necessary for successful neurofeedback training.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical application and effectiveness of real-time fMRI neurofeedback training in improving depression severity scores in patients with clinical depression.
results_summary: The study found a tendency favoring rt-fMRI-nf for improving depression severity, but the overall effect was not statistically significant. Changes in brain activation patterns were observed, but only one study confirmed successful regulation during a transfer run.
population_specificity: Patients with clinical depression

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether single-session fNIRS neurofeedback training could enhance working memory (WM) by increasing left DLPFC activity and whether these effects persisted without feedback.
results_summary: The study found that participants successfully increased left DLPFC activity during neurofeedback training, with subsequent fMRI showing increased bilateral DLPFC activity and altered connectivity during WM tasks, though no behavioral WM performance differences were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals (N = 62)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether elderly individuals with subjective memory complaints could learn to modulate their brain activity through EEG-neurofeedback training and whether this neuromodulation could enhance cognitive abilities.
results_summary: The study found that participants undergoing EEG-neurofeedback training significantly modulated their Gamma-band synchronization, a biomarker linked to cognitive decline, compared to sham feedback. However, this neuromodulation did not translate to measurable cognitive improvements, possibly due to high baseline cognitive performance.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with subjective memory complaints.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of neurofeedback training and perceptual-motor exercises in improving visual attention in children with ADHD.
results_summary: Both neurofeedback training and perceptual-motor exercises significantly improved attention-related measures (reaction time, omission, and commission errors), with no significant difference between the two interventions. However, perceptual-motor exercises also improved motor proficiency, making them a more comprehensive option.
population_specificity: 40 medicated children with ADHD, aged 5-12 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the feasibility and effectiveness of individualized beta rhythm neurofeedback training (NFT) compared to fixed beta rhythm NFT for improving attention in children with ADHD.
results_summary: Both individualized and fixed beta rhythm NFT significantly improved attention, increased beta power, reduced ADHD-RS scores, and enhanced behavioral and EEG features, with individualized training showing superior improvements in ADHD-RS scores. Brain rhythm distribution shifted toward higher frequencies post-intervention.
population_specificity: 55 children with ADHD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of neurofeedback training as an intervention for children with trauma, particularly in complementing traditional therapies like TF-CBT.
results_summary: The review found some benefits from neurofeedback training, but studies were small, varied in treatment length and intensity, and showed inconsistent benefits compared to usual treatments. Further research with standardized protocols and clearer target groups is needed.
population_specificity: Children/young people who experienced traumatic events or demonstrated trauma symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate different EEG theta and/or beta frequency band neurofeedback protocols to enhance cognitive control in children and adolescents with ADHD.
results_summary: All neurofeedback protocols reduced ADHD symptoms, but only those enhancing beta frequencies (with or without theta regulation) improved cognitive control functions like response inhibition and conflict control. The widely used theta/beta protocol showed comparatively limited effects.
population_specificity: 157 children and adolescents (129 with ADHD, 28 typically developing controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neurofeedback training combined with SmartMind game improves time perception, attention, and working memory in children with ADHD.
results_summary: Neurofeedback training significantly improved short- and long-time perception, attention (reduced omission errors, increased correct responses in CPT), and visual forward working memory, but had no significant effect on commission errors or other working memory components.
population_specificity: 32 male students diagnosed with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether EEG infraslow neurofeedback (ISF-NF) training alters effective connectivity and whether these changes correlate with improvements in pain and disability in chronic low back pain patients.
results_summary: ISF-NF targeting the pgACC significantly increased effective connectivity between pgACC and S1L, which negatively correlated with pain severity at one-month follow-up, suggesting pain reduction via connectivity modulation. Significant differences were observed between ISF-NF and Sham-NF groups in connectivity changes.
population_specificity: 60 participants with chronic low back pain.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated; assessments were done post-intervention, at one-week, and one-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neurofeedback training could change phantom hand representation and modulate pain without explicit phantom hand movements or hand-like visual feedback.
results_summary: Neurofeedback training significantly increased pain after contralateral training compared to ipsilateral training, and improved classification accuracy of phantom hand movements only after contralateral training, suggesting it can modulate pain and alter phantom hand representation.
population_specificity: Fourteen patients with phantom limb pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of individualized neurofeedback training (INT) versus non-individualized neurofeedback training (NINT) for improving attention using fNIRS.
results_summary: The INT group showed a higher improvement rate in maintaining oxygenated hemoglobin concentration above a threshold and a more significant decline in reaction times compared to the NINT group. The INT group also exhibited higher activation in prefrontal areas, suggesting better attention improvement.
population_specificity: Not specified (participants underwent neurofeedback training)
study_duration: Four runs of neurofeedback training (duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility, safety, and clinical outcomes of EEG-based infraslow fluctuation neurofeedback (ISF-NF) training for pain management in people with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: The study found ISF-NF training feasible, safe, and acceptable, with high perceived effectiveness. Pain and functional outcomes showed variability, with some improvements noted, while EEG data indicated frequency-specific neuronal activity and connectivity changes post-training.
population_specificity: Middle-aged (61.7 ± 7.6 years), predominantly New Zealand European (90.5%), mostly female (62%) individuals with KOA and an average knee pain duration of 4 ± 3.4 years.
effective_dosage: Nine 30-minute ISF-NF training sessions targeting three cortical regions linked to pain.
study_duration: Intervention spanned nine sessions (duration per session: 30 minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether amygdala-based real-time fMRI neurofeedback training could reshape abnormal regional homogeneity (ReHo) in brain regions and improve sleep in patients with chronic insomnia disorder (CID).
results_summary: The study found that neurofeedback training decreased ReHo values in certain prefrontal and motor areas while increasing them in the cerebellum, alongside significant reductions in clinical scores related to sleep quality, insomnia severity, depression, and anxiety. Correlations were observed between ReHo changes and improvements in depression and anxiety scores.
population_specificity: 28 patients with chronic insomnia disorder (CID)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how neurofeedback training affects the contingent negative variation (CNV) in adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and whether impulsivity moderates these effects.
results_summary: Neurofeedback training altered CNV amplitude depending on impulsivity levels—participants with low impulsivity showed decreased CNV, while those with high impulsivity showed increased CNV. The control group exhibited no change or decreased CNV after standard treatment.
population_specificity: Adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (ASD)
effective_dosage: 24 sessions of slow cortical potential (SCP) neurofeedback training

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of theta/beta-based neurofeedback (T/B NF) training for improving attention in children with ADHD.
results_summary: T/B NF showed medium within-group effects post-treatment and large effects at follow-up, outperforming waitlist control and physical activities but not stimulant medication. The study concluded that T/B NF benefits attention in children with ADHD, though findings should be interpreted cautiously.
population_specificity: Children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Neurofeedback Training on aggression and impulsivity in schoolchildren with ADHD.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in aggression and impulsivity scores (BPAQ and BIS) in the Neurofeedback group, with large effect sizes, supporting its clinical applicability for ADHD symptoms.
population_specificity: 40 male elementary school children with ADHD (aged 11.17±0.97 years).
effective_dosage: 12 sessions, each 60 minutes, twice a week for six weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether strengthening GABA activity via neurofeedback training (NFT) could influence subsequent motor learning.
results_summary: The study found that NFT strengthened GABA activity and suppressed online motor learning but did not affect offline learning, suggesting prior GABA modulation may impact online motor learning.
population_specificity: Thirty-six healthy participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether amygdala-based real-time fMRI neurofeedback training could alter intrinsic functional hubs, reshape abnormal functional connections, and improve sleep in patients with chronic insomnia disorder.
results_summary: The study found that neurofeedback training led to changes in functional connectivity in specific brain regions and improved clinical scores related to sleep quality, insomnia severity, depression, and anxiety. A positive correlation was observed between changes in insomnia severity and activity in the right insula.
population_specificity: 28 patients with chronic insomnia disorder (CID).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the lasting effects of neurofeedback training (reinforcing theta reduction) on EEG changes and cognitive improvement in older adults with excessive theta activity.
results_summary: The experimental group showed global EEG changes (delta/theta decreases, beta increases) and significant cognitive improvement after one year, while the control group only exhibited localized theta reduction. The benefits persisted for at least one year.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults with excessive theta activity in their EEG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single session of SMR-based neurofeedback training could improve selective attention and alter brain-heart interplay in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The NFb group showed improved Stroop task performance, particularly in incongruent trials, with multifractality and NFb efficacy predicting performance gains. The study concluded that a single SMR-NFb session enhances selective attention via reorganization of brain-heart dynamics.
population_specificity: Young healthy participants (n = 35, 20 females, aged 21 ± 3 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify resting-state functional brain connectivity markers that predict individual neurofeedback (NF) aptitude, independent of NF-targeting brain regions.
results_summary: The study identified six resting-state functional connectivity (FC) markers predictive of NF aptitude, with the posterior cingulate cortex as a functional hub, suggesting NF aptitude may relate to attentional modulation in resting-state brain activity. The prediction model was validated across independent datasets.
population_specificity: 59 healthy adults and six patients with major depressive disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of neurofeedback training on male and female adolescents with ASD, examining sex differences in improvements of psychopathological symptoms, cognitive flexibility, and emotion recognition abilities.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant sex-related differences in outcomes, though males tended to report greater improvements in externalizing, internalizing, and total symptoms, while females showed smaller improvements in externalizing and total problems but no improvement in internalizing issues. Caregivers noted more improvement in total problems for females and improvements in internalizing and total problems for males.
population_specificity: 12 adolescents (6 male, 6 female) with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), matched by age, IQ, and symptom severity.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied by the 24 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neurofeedback training (NFT) could improve the performance of a steady-state visual evoked potential (SSVEP)-based brain-computer interface (BCI) and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: NFT increased the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), accuracy, and information transfer rate (ITR) of the SSVEP-based BCI by 5.8%, 4.7%, and 15.6%, respectively, while no improvement was observed in the control group. The study also found enhanced information flow from the parietal to the occipital lobe and improved attention, suggesting NFT modulates the control network.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract does not detail participant demographics).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a new neurofeedback (NFB) treatment protocol for ADHD by analyzing EEG signals and identifying distinguishing features between healthy controls and children with ADHD.
results_summary: The study found that EEG-TBR values in children with ADHD were lower than in healthy peers, but the difference was not statistically significant. A new NFB protocol was proposed, focusing on inhibiting alpha band activity and enhancing delta activity in specific channels (F7 or T5), along with reinforced beta-band activity, to treat ADHD symptoms.
population_specificity: 30 healthy controls and 30 children with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the importance of the motivational value versus the purely informational value of reinforcers in Neurofeedback Training success.
results_summary: Only subjects in the selected reinforcer group receiving real Neurofeedback Training increased their sensorimotor rhythm (SMR). The study found no significant differences between groups at baseline, highlighting the motivational value of reinforcers as a key factor in Neurofeedback success.
population_specificity: 113 subjects randomly assigned to different reinforcer conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether real-time fMRI neurofeedback training could modulate craving-related neural activation and improve abstinence rates in patients with alcohol dependence.
results_summary: The study found that neurofeedback training modulated addiction-associated brain responses, with decreased activation in medial frontal areas/caudate nucleus and increased activation in cuneus/precuneus and occipital cortex. However, it did not demonstrate clinically superior abstinence rates for the active neurofeedback group after 3 months.
population_specificity: 52 patients (45 male, 7 female) diagnosed with alcohol dependence in Munich, Germany.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but follow-up was 3 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dynamic parameters of alpha states (e.g., fractional occupancy, dwell time, transition probability) during alpha-neurofeedback training correlate with changes in pain resilience in chronic pain patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant change in mean frontal alpha power but observed trends of increased fractional occupancy, dwell time, and transition probability in chronic pain patients. These dynamic parameters significantly correlated with reduced pain scores in chronic pain patients but not in healthy participants.
population_specificity: Four chronic pain patients and four healthy participants.
effective_dosage: Five neurofeedback sessions designed to increase frontal alpha power.
study_duration: Five sessions (exact duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and effects of rtfMRI-based neurofeedback training (NFT) in preventing relapse among alcohol-dependent patients.
results_summary: The study found very low relapse rates in both groups, with the treatment group successfully modulating brain activity in the salience network as intended. The intervention showed good safety and acceptability.
population_specificity: Alcohol-dependent patients from the UK who had completed a detoxification program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of neurofeedback training as an additional treatment for major depressive disorder (MDD) patients not achieving remission with standard care.
results_summary: Most studies showed that MDD patients experienced symptom improvement superior to control groups, but many studies lacked stringent quality and reporting standards.
population_specificity: Patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) not reaching remission from standard care (psychopharmacology and psychotherapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of neurofeedback training, behavior management, and medication (methylphenidate) in improving symptoms of ADHD in children.
results_summary: Neurofeedback showed comparable efficacy to behavior management in improving core ADHD symptoms (inattention, hyperactivity, executive functioning) but was superior for learning problems. Medication was most effective for core symptoms, while neurofeedback and medication had similar benefits for peer relations.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-12 years diagnosed with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of EEG-based neurofeedback training in occupational therapy for upper limb stroke rehabilitation.
results_summary: Most studies reported significant improvements from EEG-based neurofeedback training, which was more effective than traditional treatment and even more so when combined with EEG. However, differences in effectiveness between groups were not always accounted for.
population_specificity: Patients with upper limb stroke undergoing rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether neurofeedback training targeting positive self-processing could serve as a potential treatment alternative for adolescent depression.
results_summary: Depressed youth showed altered amygdala-frontocortical connectivity during neurofeedback, with symptom reduction observed. Right amygdala connectivity correlated positively with rumination and depression change, while left amygdala connectivity correlated negatively with depression change.
population_specificity: Adolescents with depression.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of real-time neurofeedback training in modulating speech-related/language-related brain networks to control auditory verbal hallucinations (AVH) in schizophrenia patients.
results_summary: EEG-based neurofeedback failed to regulate auditory-evoked potentials or reduce AVH, while fMRI-based neurofeedback showed promise in downregulating superior temporal gyrus hyperactivity and upregulating anterior cingulate cortex activity, alleviating treatment-resistant AVH. The study highlights the need for better methodologies and deeper understanding of AVH mechanisms.
population_specificity: Schizophrenia patients with treatment-resistant auditory verbal hallucinations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of two neurofeedback training methods (activity and connectivity real-time fMRI) in managing cognitive symptoms in Huntington's disease gene-carriers.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significantly higher neurofeedback target levels during training compared to controls, but no robust evidence of transfer to cognitive or psychomotor function improvements was found, nor a difference between the two neurofeedback methods.
population_specificity: Huntington's disease gene-carriers (n=32)
study_duration: Training sessions followed by follow-up assessments at 2 months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze a neurofeedback-based video game framework for enhancing attention and concentration skills in children with ADHD.
results_summary: The study proposed a neurofeedback video game approach for ADHD treatment, highlighting its potential to improve attention and concentration, while also discussing limitations and future research directions.
population_specificity: Children with ADHD or ADD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sensorimotor (SMR)/theta neurofeedback training could improve cognitive performance and brain electrical activity in elderly patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in cognitive assessments (MoCa, RAVLT, Forward digit span, WAIS-IV, Mac Nair score) and EEG theta/alpha power after neurofeedback training, with sustained effects at a 1-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
effective_dosage: 20 sessions over 10 weeks (2 sessions per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Neurofeedback Training (NFT) could improve PTSD symptoms, behavioral and emotional symptoms, and executive functioning in children with developmental trauma who had not responded to previous therapies.
results_summary: The study found that 24 sessions of NFT significantly reduced PTSD symptoms, internalizing and externalizing behaviors, and improved executive functioning in children with severe histories of abuse and neglect. The active NFT group showed better outcomes compared to the treatment-as-usual control group.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-13 years with developmental trauma (history of abuse and neglect) who had not significantly benefited from previous therapies.
effective_dosage: 24 NFT sessions, administered twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors determining the success of Neurofeedback Training (NF) to develop individualized protocols and clinical indications.
results_summary: The study found mixed efficacy for NF, with some participants failing to self-regulate brain activity ("non-learners") and standardized protocols potentially lacking individualization. Neurophysiological baseline parameters, particularly the target training parameters, showed the strongest evidence as predictors of NF success.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals, patients with mental disorders, and epilepsy patients.
study_duration: At least two sessions (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha/delta neurofeedback training is effective in reducing tinnitus sound perception and associated psychological symptoms compared to beta/theta neurofeedback or a diary control group.
results_summary: The study found that alpha/delta neurofeedback training showed promise in reducing tinnitus perception and distress, with comparisons made against active and passive control groups to assess specificity and placebo effects. Secondary outcomes included improvements in sleep quality, depressive symptoms, and changes in trained frequency bands.
population_specificity: Individuals with tinnitus.
effective_dosage: 10 sessions over 4 weeks for neurofeedback groups; bi-weekly diary for the control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a NeuroFeedback (NF) training protocol on drivers to observe its impact on attentional skills and psychophysiological stress levels related to driving behavior.
results_summary: The study found that NF training improved driving behavior performance, reduced violations, increased heart rate and Stroop Task accuracy, and reduced reaction times in the experimental group, indicating enhanced attentional efficiency and behavioral improvement.
population_specificity: 50 drivers randomly assigned to experimental and control groups.
effective_dosage: 21-day mindfulness NF training with incremental duration sessions (specific duration per session not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neurofeedback training (NFB) specifically modifies trained EEG frequencies and whether untrained frequencies are affected, comparing it to HRV biofeedback.
results_summary: The study found that both HRV and HRV/NFB groups exhibited EEG changes, with untrained frequencies significantly modified in the HRV/NFB group, suggesting broader effects than just the trained frequencies. EEG activity was altered in both groups, indicating changes were not limited to the trained bands or modality.
population_specificity: Participants randomly assigned to HRV biofeedback or HRV/NFB training groups (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: To investigate the effect of frequency-neurofeedback on working memory in children with ADHD and determine if the effect is long-lasting.
results_summary: Neurofeedback training significantly improved working memory in children with ADHD, with correct responses increasing from 43% to 69% post-training and maintaining at 71% a year later, compared to minimal improvements in the control group.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-12 with ADHD, average intelligence, and no concurrent ADHD treatments.
effective_dosage: 10-12 sessions over 10 weeks, with frequency bands for theta and beta ranges adjusted based on each child's peak alpha frequency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether alpha neurofeedback training could improve cognitive and motor functions in chronic stroke patients who had plateaued with traditional therapies.
results_summary: Both patients showed enhanced alpha activity during neurofeedback training, reduced anxiety and depression levels, and exhibited improvements in speech patterns (male) and motor functionality (female). The results suggest neurofeedback training may offer benefits for chronic stroke patients unresponsive to conventional treatments.
population_specificity: Two chronic stroke patients (63-year-old male and 77-year-old female) with ischemic stroke lasting over 3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interpersonal mechanisms affecting forensic psychiatric patients' ability to respond to neurofeedback and assess its effects on impulsivity and craving.
results_summary: One patient showed behavioral improvements (reduced impulsivity and craving), but these findings could not be attributed to neurofeedback. The study found insufficient evidence for the efficacy of theta/SMR neurofeedback on impulsivity and craving, highlighting interindividual differences in cortical regulation.
population_specificity: Four forensic psychiatric patients with DSM-IV-TR substance use disorder and various comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of physical activity and neurofeedback training on postural stability and fall risk in elderly women.
results_summary: Neurofeedback training significantly improved postural stability and reduced fall risk compared to both physical activity and control groups, with statistically significant results (P < .05). The study found neurofeedback to be superior to physical activity in these outcomes (P = .005).
population_specificity: Physically independent women older than 65 years living in an elderly care center in Shiraz.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, 3 days per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of a game-based neurofeedback training (NFT) system in improving cognitive performance in women with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI) and healthy elderly subjects.
results_summary: NFT significantly improved rapid visual processing and spatial working memory (including strategy) compared to exergame training and no active treatment, but had no significant effect on pattern recognition memory or short-term visual memory.
population_specificity: 65 women with aMCI and 54 healthy elderly women.
effective_dosage: 20 sessions of 30 minutes each, 2-3 sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how neurofeedback training targeting the left amygdala affects the amygdala network involved in facial expression tasks and its correlation with behavioral performance.
results_summary: The study found that neurofeedback training enhanced both the activity of the amygdala network and the functional connectivity between the fusiform and amygdala, with increased connectivity correlating with improved behavioral performance in facial emotional perception.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether theta/SMR neurofeedback training could reduce impulsivity, drug craving, and drug intake in forensic psychiatric patients with substance use disorders (SUD).
results_summary: Neurofeedback training increased SMR magnitude but did not significantly improve impulsivity, drug craving, or drug intake compared to treatment-as-usual (TAU). The intervention was not more effective than TAU alone.
population_specificity: Forensic psychiatric patients diagnosed with SUD.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not specified (number of sessions: 20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between EEG theta/beta ratio and processing speed in MS patients and explore whether neurofeedback training could alter this ratio to improve processing speed.
results_summary: The study found that MS patients with slower processing speed had an increased theta/beta ratio, driven by higher theta power. Neurofeedback training did not significantly alter the theta/beta ratio across sessions but showed a transient reduction in theta activity within sessions.
population_specificity: 58 multiple sclerosis patients (RRMS/SPMS/PPMS), with 10 receiving neurofeedback training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neurofeedback training could improve cognitive functions (memory, attention) and brain electrical activity in elderly patients with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study protocol outlines plans to evaluate cognitive performance and EEG activity changes post-neurofeedback training, but results are not yet reported in the abstract. The potential for NF to delay cognitive decline is discussed as a possible outcome.
population_specificity: Older adults with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI).
effective_dosage: 30 sessions of sensorimotor/delta-ratio NF training or beta1/theta-ratio NF training (specific frequency/duration per session not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of NIRS neurofeedback training targeting the dlPFC and its effects on threat-related attention biases in individuals with social anxiety disorder (SAD).
results_summary: Neurofeedback performance improved significantly, while attention bias towards threat-related stimuli and SAD symptom severity decreased post-training. Individual improvements in neurofeedback performance and symptom reduction correlated with decreased responses to social threat signals in the attention system.
population_specificity: 12 individuals with social anxiety disorder (SAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a novel automated reward thresholding algorithm (progressive thresholding) in improving learning outcomes for frontal alpha asymmetry neurofeedback training compared to existing automatic algorithms.
results_summary: The study found that progressive thresholding significantly improved learning outcomes over current automatic reward thresholding algorithms in a double-blind comparison, suggesting better simulation of clinician-guided threshold adjustments.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract does not detail participant demographics or clinical conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of neurofeedback training with and without Ritalin in treating children with ADHD.
results_summary: The study found that neurofeedback improved some behavioral aspects of ADHD, but the combination of neurofeedback and Ritalin was more effective, particularly in reducing commission errors and reaction time in the CPT and modifying F4 theta/alpha ratios.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-10 years diagnosed with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of EEG neurofeedback training (NFT) in improving cognitive functions and reducing ADHD symptoms in children.
results_summary: The study found that NFT improved cognitive functions (sustained attention, verbal working memory, and response inhibition), reduced parent- and teacher-rated behavior problems, and enhanced academic performance. Improvements were sustained at a 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-12 years diagnosed with ADHD, with or without comorbid conditions.
effective_dosage: 40 sessions of theta/beta NFT at the C3 scalp location, 3-4 sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if neurofeedback training could normalize abnormal brain waves (high-beta and low alpha) linked to hyperarousal and improve autonomous regulation in individuals with alcohol use disorders.
results_summary: Neurofeedback training increased alpha waves and decreased high-beta waves in most sites (though not significantly) and significantly improved psychological need satisfaction, abstinence self-efficacy, and self-regulation compared to the control group. However, significant attenuation of hyperarousal may require more sessions.
population_specificity: 36 Korean inpatients meeting Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of neurofeedback training on reducing stress and enhancing self-regulation in late adolescents to assess its potential as a nursing intervention.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in stress biomarkers (HRV and SCL), reductions in negative affect and symptoms of obsessive-compulsive behavior and depression, and enhanced self-regulation in the neurofeedback group compared to controls.
population_specificity: Late adolescents (n=78, split into experimental and control groups).
effective_dosage: 10 sessions of 30 minutes each, with high-beta, theta, and sensory motor rhythm training.
study_duration: Total intervention duration not specified beyond 10 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the applicability and effectiveness of neurofeedback training in criminal offender populations, focusing on disorders like ADHD, SUD, schizophrenia, and psychopathy.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with behavioral improvements ranging from none to significant symptom reduction, and inconsistent changes in targeted EEG-frequency bands. Only three studies established criteria for EEG-learning, and no studies were identified for neurofeedback in aggression, violence, or recidivism.
population_specificity: Adult criminal offenders with disorders such as ADHD, SUD, schizophrenia, and psychopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of fMRI-based Neurofeedback Training (NFT) to modulate brain function, both in healthy individuals and those with neurologic disorders, by developing a protocol for targeted cognitive and auditory region training.
results_summary: The study found that fMRI NFT enables volitional control over various brain regions, with applications in treating neurologic disorders and enhancing baseline performance. The method is non-invasive, non-pharmacologic, and has no known side effects, showing promise across cognitive, behavioral, and motor systems.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied to include both healthy individuals and those with neurologic disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effectiveness of EEG neurofeedback training on clinical symptoms, perceived stress, and cortisol levels in traumatic brain injury (TBI) patients, particularly in the context of spontaneous recovery.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in symptom reporting, perceived stress, and cortisol levels between the neurofeedback training (NFT) group and the treatment-as-usual (TAU) group, indicating beneficial effects of alpha-theta NFT on symptom reduction and stress.
population_specificity: 60 TBI patients, half recruited within 6 months of injury and the other half between 12-18 months post-injury.
effective_dosage: Alpha-theta training over 20 sessions (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to span the 20 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pharmacological treatment influences the efficacy of vibrotactile neurofeedback training (IVNT) in patients with chronic, noncompensated vestibulopathies.
results_summary: Both groups showed statistically significant improvement in postural stability and dizziness symptoms after IVNT, with long-term efficacy observed at 6 months. The addition of antivertiginous medication did not hinder IVNT's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic, noncompensated vestibulopathies and disabling vertigo of different origins.
effective_dosage: IVNT for ~10 min daily; medication group received 20 mg cinnarizine and 40 mg dimenhydrinate per tablet, three tablets daily.
study_duration: 2 weeks of IVNT, with follow-up at 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether real-time fMRI neurofeedback training could counteract cognitive decline in healthy elderly individuals and patients with prodromal Alzheimer's disease by targeting visuospatial memory and the parahippocampal gyrus.
results_summary: Both healthy elderly subjects and prodromal AD patients showed improved visuospatial memory after neurofeedback training, with healthy subjects also improving in working memory and cognitive assessment scores. The training led to changes in cerebral connectivity and grey matter volume increases in the precuneus and frontal cortex, while no such effects were observed in the sham-feedback control group.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly subjects (mean age 63.5 years) and patients with prodromal Alzheimer's disease (mean age 66.2 years).
study_duration: Five examination days (T1-T5), with neurofeedback training occurring over three days (T2-T4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of short but intensive neurofeedback training on cognitive, behavioral, and emotional functions in a schizophrenic patient.
results_summary: The study found that intensive neurofeedback training increased alpha/beta2 activity, improved short-term memory, mood, and speech patterns, and led to dramatic symptom improvement at a 22-month follow-up.
population_specificity: A middle-aged woman with chronic schizophrenia.
effective_dosage: 13.5 hours of alpha/beta2 (20-30 Hz) neurofeedback training over four consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify pre-training assessment indices that could predict which children with ADHD would successfully learn self-regulation through neurofeedback training.
results_summary: The study found a learner rate of 45.5% in neurofeedback training, with learners predicted by pre-training cognitive and neurophysiological measures related to Stroop tasks, suggesting intact executive function as a characteristic of successful learners. Neurofeedback training was not universally effective for children with ADHD, highlighting the need for further research to establish application criteria.
population_specificity: 22 children with ADHD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neurofeedback training (NFT) could improve bimanual coordination in children with ADHD compared to a control condition.
results_summary: NFT significantly improved bimanual coordination accuracy and consistency in children with ADHD, with fewer errors compared to the control group. The improvements were observed over multiple assessments and persisted post-intervention.
population_specificity: 20 children with ADHD (mean age 7.9 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (SMR training at C3 and C4 electrodes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether real-time fMRI neurofeedback training targeting the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC) could reduce ADHD symptoms and improve cognitive functioning in adults with ADHD.
results_summary: Both neurofeedback and control groups showed increased dACC activation, but only neurofeedback participants demonstrated stronger cognitive improvement. No significant difference in clinical symptom reduction was found between groups.
population_specificity: Adults with ADHD (n = 13 total, 7 in neurofeedback group, 6 in control group).
effective_dosage: Four weekly MRI training sessions (60 minutes per session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of neurofeedback training on EEG changes in adults with forward head posture and its potential benefits for concentration, relaxation, and cognitive performance.
results_summary: Neurofeedback training showed significant effects on Delta, Beta, and sensory motor rhythm waves between groups, suggesting improvements in concentration, relaxation, and cognitive performance. The intervention was deemed effective for improving neck pain and daily activities.
population_specificity: 40 college students with forward head posture.
effective_dosage: Six sessions of pottery and archery games, each for two minutes, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of neurofeedback training (NFT) in virtual reality (VR) versus 2D environments and biofeedback training in VR for improving ADHD symptoms, self-control, executive functions, and school performance in children with ADHD.
results_summary: The study is designed to evaluate the effects of NFT in VR and 2D environments, but results are not yet reported in the abstract. The study will assess ADHD symptoms, self-control, executive functions, school performance, and motor activity pre- and post-intervention, as well as at a 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Children with a clinical diagnosis of ADHD, either medicated or unmedicated.
study_duration: 15 training sessions (duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of neurofeedback training on postural changes in the cervical spine, neck range of motion, and Neck Disability Index in adults with forward head posture.
results_summary: Neurofeedback training showed no significant effects on absolute rotation angle, anterior weight bearing, or range of extension and flexion, but significantly improved Neck Disability Index scores pre- and post-intervention and compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 40 college students with forward head posture.
effective_dosage: Six sessions of pottery and archery games, each for two minutes, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of neurofeedback training (NFBT) for treating ADHD and identify promising areas for further research.
results_summary: The study reviewed existing data on NFBT for ADHD, highlighting its mechanisms and effectiveness, and identified areas needing further investigation.
population_specificity: Individuals with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rtfMRI neurofeedback training (NFT) could help alcohol-dependent patients regulate brain activation in response to alcohol or healthy stimuli and whether this would reduce alcohol consumption.
results_summary: The study found preliminary evidence that rtfMRI NFT may help patients regulate brain activation, with potential reductions in alcohol consumption measured by days abstinent, drinks per drinking day, and heavy drinking days, though final results were pending follow-up.
population_specificity: Alcohol-dependent patients who completed detoxification and remained abstinent for up to 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha neurofeedback training (NFT) could enhance working and episodic memory in healthy participants and assess its trainability.
results_summary: The Alpha group showed significant increases in alpha amplitude and duration, leading to improved accuracies in working and episodic memory tasks, particularly for participants with notable alpha-amplitude increases. No adverse effects were reported, and questionnaire scores remained within normal ranges.
population_specificity: Fifty healthy participants.
effective_dosage: Three NFT sessions per week (8-12 Hz amplitude for Alpha group, random 4 Hz amplitude from 7-20 Hz for Ctrl group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neurofeedback training improves mental health and reduces substance craving in opiate-dependent patients undergoing pharmacotherapy.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in somatic symptoms, depression, general mental health, and reductions in opioid craving compared to the control group. The study supports neurofeedback as an effective supplementary treatment for opiate dependence.
population_specificity: 20 opiate-dependent patients receiving Methadone or Buprenorphine maintenance treatment.
effective_dosage: 30 sessions of neurofeedback (sensory motor rhythm training on Cz followed by alpha-theta protocol on Pz).
study_duration: Duration of neurofeedback sessions not specified; total intervention involved 30 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term effects of PNF stretching alone versus PNF combined with NMES on hamstring extensibility and vertical jump capacity in young basketball players.
results_summary: Both PNF and PNF + NMES significantly improved hamstring flexibility but showed no significant differences between groups or in vertical jump capacity.
population_specificity: Young male basketball players (n=45).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and clinical outcomes of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) in patients with fragility fractures.
results_summary: The study found that NMES was feasible in mildly frail fragility fracture patients, with 53% achieving the target of 24 sessions, but 5/29 withdrew due to intolerance. Muscle strength improved in both treated and untreated legs, with slightly greater improvement in the tibialis anterior of treated legs.
population_specificity: Patients with fragility fractures, excluding those with mobility issues, contraindications to NMES, or inability to give consent.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes, 3 days/week initially, progressing to 60 minutes, 5-7 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of repetitive peripheral magnetic stimulation (rPMS) versus neuromuscular stimulation (NMS) in improving upper extremity function, spasticity, and activities of daily living in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study is designed to evaluate whether rPMS is superior to NMS, but results are not yet provided in the abstract. The primary outcome measure is the change in Fugl-Meyer Assessment for Upper Extremity, with secondary outcomes including changes in daily living independence and spasticity scales.
population_specificity: Patients with subacute stroke and spastic hemiparesis.
effective_dosage: Five days a week for three weeks (frequency and duration specified, but exact stimulation parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the advancements, benefits, and challenges of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) in rehabilitation, muscle activation, and broader health applications.
results_summary: NMES shows significant benefits in rehabilitation, post-exercise recovery, blood glucose uptake, and venous return, but faces challenges in user compliance due to discomfort and improper electrode placement. Innovations like automated stimulation point location and wearable technologies aim to improve adherence and efficacy.
population_specificity: Individuals experiencing immobilization or physical disability, and broader populations for health and wellness applications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of different NMES frequencies (low, high, and mixed) on cortical and spinal excitability.
results_summary: Mixed-frequency NMES was most effective in modulating corticospinal excitability, though motor performance remained unaffected. All frequencies prolonged the cortical silent period and inhibited Mmax, while F-wave and MVC were unchanged.
population_specificity: Thirteen able-bodied individuals.
effective_dosage: Motor-level NMES at 120% of individual motor threshold, applied in 10 sec ON / 10 sec OFF duty cycles for 10 min.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a single NMES treatment on lumbar multifidus stiffness and pain intensity in individuals with chronic low back pain (CLBP).
results_summary: The study found significant changes in multifidus stiffness in the 'combined' intervention group, particularly at L4 and L5, while both groups experienced significant reductions in pain intensity.
population_specificity: 30 participants (13 male, 17 female) with chronic low back pain.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention protocols: 'phasic' and 'combined' with the StimaWELL 120MTRS system).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how NMES waveform shape and BFR occlusion pressure acutely influence electrically elicited force (EEF) and tissue oxygen saturation (StO2) of the knee extensors.
results_summary: VMS and VMS-Burst waveforms led to higher EEF compared to RUS with 60% LOP, while 80% LOP resulted in lower EEF compared to 0% LOP with VMS. No significant differences in StO2 were observed between NMES waveforms or BFR occlusion pressures.
population_specificity: Two groups of 15 participants (total 30) with no further demographic details provided.
effective_dosage: 3 sets of 10 NMES contractions per set, with 5 minutes of passive interset recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the functional localization of neural changes following neurofeedback training (NF) compared to an active control condition and assess the role of successful learning during training in improving ADHD symptoms.
results_summary: Children in the NF group showed reduced ADHD symptoms and increased activation in brain areas linked to inhibitory control. Successful learners, regardless of training type, exhibited enhanced activation in an extensive inhibitory network.
population_specificity: Children with ADHD (N=16, mean age: 11.81, SD: 1.47).
effective_dosage: 20 sessions of training (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated beyond the number of sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) for venous thromboprophylaxis in surgical patients undergoing elective surgery.
results_summary: NMES significantly reduced the incidence of postoperative deep venous thrombosis and improved postoperative D-dimer levels and femoral venous peak velocity compared to basic thromboprophylaxis and other mechanical methods. No NMES device-related adverse events were reported, but the certainty of evidence was low to very low.
population_specificity: Surgical patients undergoing elective surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of subtetanic neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) combined with active recovery on blood lactate accumulation, sprint performance, and muscle fatigue.
results_summary: NMES combined with voluntary cycling increased blood lactate accumulation and induced greater voluntary fatigue but did not affect sprint performance or peripheral muscle fatigue compared to voluntary cycling alone.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy young individuals (23±4 years, 10 males).
study_duration: Single session (four 15-sec sprints with three 5-min active recovery periods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of VL-selective fatigue induced by NMES on knee extensor EMG activity during a sustained submaximal isometric contraction.
results_summary: NMES-induced VL fatigue reduced time to task failure by 23% and increased EMG activity in synergist muscles, but did not alter the extent or origin of neuromuscular fatigue at task failure.
population_specificity: Thirteen healthy men (28 ± 5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) could mitigate impairments from disuse when applied during immobilization for upper and lower extremity musculoskeletal conditions.
results_summary: NMES improved quadriceps atrophy and strength outcomes in four out of six studies, but the literature is limited to outdated models and small sample sizes, highlighting a need for further research.
population_specificity: Patients with anterior cruciate ligament repair and tibia fracture.
effective_dosage: NMES duration ranged from 40 minutes to 8 hours a day, with alternating current ramping up over 0.4 to 4 seconds, contraction duration between 2 and 20 seconds, and rest times between 5 and 50 seconds.
study_duration: Immobilization periods lasted four to six weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and effectiveness of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) in enhancing functional capacity and mobility in pre- and post-cardiac surgery patients.
results_summary: NMES was generally safe and feasible, with improvements in muscle strength and 6-minute walking test distances, particularly in preoperative settings, but postoperative benefits were inconsistent. The study noted challenges like short ICU stays and body composition affecting efficacy, and suggested further research to optimize protocols.
population_specificity: Pre- and post-cardiac surgery patients, with potential relevance to other conditions like cerebral palsy and stroke.
effective_dosage: Intervention sessions varied in frequency and duration (specifics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether protein supplementation enhances the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation resistance training (NMES-RT) on lean mass and cardiometabolic health in individuals with chronic spinal cord injury.
results_summary: NMES-RT increased thigh lean mass, with greater gains observed in the protein-supplemented group. Both groups showed similar improvements in fasting insulin and insulin resistance, suggesting potential cardiometabolic benefits.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic spinal cord injury (n=15).
effective_dosage: NMES-RT administered 3 times/week (protein supplementation dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined neuromuscular electrical stimulation (Comb-NMES) could preserve muscle cross-sectional area and modulate inflammatory signaling in individuals with acute spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Comb-NMES showed potential preservation of muscle cross-sectional area and beneficial modulation of inflammatory markers (e.g., downregulation of TLR4 and Atrogin-1) compared to controls, suggesting attenuation of muscle atrophy pathways. However, small sample size and injury variability limit generalizability.
population_specificity: Individuals with acute spinal cord injury (SCI).
effective_dosage: Not specified (novel Comb-NMES regimen integrating high-frequency resistance and low-frequency aerobic protocols).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of simultaneous neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) and static stretching on flexibility and muscle strength compared to NMES alone.
results_summary: The study found that simultaneous NMES and static stretching significantly improved flexibility (forward flexion distance) more than NMES alone, while ankle dorsiflexion angle improvements were similar between groups. No significant changes were observed in ankle plantar flexor strength for either group.
population_specificity: 96 healthy university students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of transcutaneous neuromuscular electrical stimulation as a non-invasive alternative for managing varicocele-induced scrotal pain.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that neuromuscular electrical stimulation has shown positive outcomes in treating andrological conditions and may offer a promising alternative to surgery for varicocele-induced scrotal pain, though further research is needed to validate its efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: Adult males with varicocele-induced scrotal pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and summarize the evidence for the potential benefits of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on improving gait patterns in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant differences in some gait measures (e.g., Ten-meter walk test) between NMES and control groups, but NMES showed improvements in quantitative gait speed, cadence, step length, ankle dorsiflexion angle, and Six-Minute Walk Test. NMES appeared more effective for chronic-phase stroke survivors and with shorter sessions.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether controlled activation of specific facial muscles via neuromuscular electrical stimulation (fNMES) could modulate emotional states, testing the facial feedback hypothesis.
results_summary: The study found that fNMES activation of the zygomaticus major muscle induced more positive emotions compared to the depressor anguli oris muscle, with effects enhanced by congruent emotional images. fNMES intensity also predicted emotional intensity ratings and physiological responses like reduced heart rate and skin conductance.
population_specificity: 58 participants (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 5-second stimulation at 100% and 50% of individual motor threshold.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the global adoption of NMES in dysphagia management, identify barriers to its adoption, and describe existing clinical practices.
results_summary: NMES is adopted by 50% of participants' workplaces globally and 42.7% in the US, with high interest but significant variability in clinical application. Over 50% of participants agreed on 19 out of 21 barriers, including insufficient academic coverage and lack of expert endorsement.
population_specificity: 171 professionals from various international backgrounds (122 responses analyzed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combinative effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation and ibuprofen on pain, hip function, and quality of life in patients with femoral head necrosis.
results_summary: The study found that combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation with ibuprofen significantly improved pain relief, hip function, quality of life, and reduced serum markers (PAI-1, leptin, osteopontin) compared to ibuprofen alone. The observation group showed better outcomes across all measured parameters.
population_specificity: 60 patients with femoral head necrosis hospitalized between Oct. 2020 and Oct. 2021.
effective_dosage: Not specified for neuromuscular electrical stimulation; ibuprofen dosage not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Muscle Pump Activation (MPA) via neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) improves calf muscle pump function and venous ulcer healing in patients with Venous Leg Ulcers (VLUs).
results_summary: The study found that MPA improves calf muscle pump function, venous return, microcirculation, and significantly accelerates venous ulcer healing when combined with compression therapy compared to compression therapy alone.
population_specificity: Patients with Venous Leg Ulcers (VLUs), including those intolerant to compression therapy or with slow-healing ulcers despite optimal compression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) could mitigate muscle mass and function loss during short-term bed rest in healthy young and old participants.
results_summary: NMES preserved muscle thickness in both young and old participants and mid-thigh lean mass in older adults, but did not prevent declines in maximal muscle strength. Late-phase rate of force development was retained in young participants with NMES, but not in older adults.
population_specificity: Healthy young and old adults undergoing 5 days of bed rest.
effective_dosage: 3 × 30 minutes per day of NMES applied to the quadriceps muscle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a hybrid training system (HTS) combining NMES and voluntary muscle contractions to overcome the limitations of traditional NMES.
results_summary: The HTS was found to enhance muscle strength, prevent atrophy, improve physical function, relieve pain, enhance fitness, and improve metabolic function. It also reduced discomfort and improved safety compared to traditional NMES.
population_specificity: Individuals with low exercise tolerance or in environments where sufficient exercise load is unavailable.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether home-based foot NMES improves self-reported function, leg pain, overall leg symptoms, and ankle blood flow in older adults with lower leg pain or symptoms.
results_summary: Foot NMES significantly improved self-reported function, leg pain, overall leg symptoms, and ankle blood flow compared to Sham, with improvements meeting minimal clinically important differences and sustained at follow-up. Compliance was high, and no device-related adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with lower leg pain and/or symptoms (e.g., cramps, tired, aching, heavy legs).
study_duration: 8 weeks of intervention with follow-up at week 12.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) and rehabilitative exercises on muscle morphology and dynamic balance in individuals with chronic ankle instability (CAI).
results_summary: The study found that NMES, either alone or combined with rehabilitative exercises, significantly improved muscle morphology and dynamic balance in CAI individuals after six weeks, except for the flexor hallucis longus muscle. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic ankle instability (n = 47).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of external neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on urinary symptoms, pelvic floor muscle strength, quality of life, sexual function, and satisfaction in women with urgency urinary incontinence (UUI).
results_summary: The NMES group showed significant improvements in urinary symptoms, pelvic floor muscle strength, quality of life, sexual function, and satisfaction compared to the sham group, with statistically significant differences (p < 0.05).
population_specificity: Women aged 18-65 years diagnosed with urgency urinary incontinence (UUI).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, three days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether simultaneous static stretching and NMES enhances physiological parameters (DFA, FFD, SLR angle) in healthy individuals and whether sex variations influence the outcomes.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in dorsiflexion angle, finger-floor distance, and straight leg raising angle after the intervention, with no significant differences between males and females.
population_specificity: 30 healthy university students (15 males, 15 females).
effective_dosage: Not specified (simultaneous static stretching and NMES for 4 minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether twice-weekly NMES-supported fingerboard training was non-inferior to thrice-weekly conventional fingerboard training in improving climbing-specific endurance.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in endurance improvements between the NMES and control groups, despite the NMES group's lower training volume. Both groups showed notable endurance gains, particularly after the in-between test, indicating NMES-supported training was non-inferior to conventional training.
population_specificity: Intermediate to advanced climbers (14 male, 4 female; mean age: 25.7 ± 5.3 years; mean climbing experience: 6.4 ± 3.4 years).
effective_dosage: Twice-weekly NMES-supported fingerboard training vs. thrice-weekly conventional fingerboard training.

study_goal: To determine the feasibility of modified constraint-induced movement therapy (mCIMT) paired with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) for infants with asymmetrical hand function (AHF).
results_summary: The study found that mCIMT-NMES was feasible and showed greater improvement in hand function scores compared to standard care, with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Infants with asymmetrical hand function at risk for unilateral cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of high-frequency facial neuromuscular electrical stimulation (fNMES) on facial aging, focusing on skin elasticity, wrinkles, sagging, and blood flow.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in skin elasticity, wrinkles, jawline angle, submental and cheek volume, nasolabial fold depth, and blood flow with fNMES intervention. Participants also reported subjective improvements in facial appearance.
population_specificity: 24 healthy adult women aged 30-59.
effective_dosage: Device operated between 40 and 190 kHz (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of remote handgrip contraction during WPHF NMES on torque production, progressive torque increase, and PIC contribution to motoneuron firing in the plantar flexors.
results_summary: The study found that while extra torque did not significantly increase with remote contraction, sustained EMG activity and ∆F (an estimate of PIC contribution) were higher, suggesting enhanced central contribution to torque production. A positive correlation was observed between ∆F change score and extra torque in the WPHF + remote condition.
population_specificity: Ten participants (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on frailty, lower limb muscle strength, and muscle quality in frail older patients with acute myocardial infarction post-PCI.
results_summary: NMES significantly reduced frailty scores and improved lower limb muscle strength and quality compared to the control group, with statistically significant differences observed at 4 and 7 days post-surgery. The intervention also showed potential benefits in activities of daily living and inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: Frail older patients (n=100) with acute myocardial infarction following PCI.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes daily on bilateral quadriceps and gastrocnemius muscles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of 12-week NMES on cognitive performance and BDNF levels in individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a clinical trial to investigate NMES effects on cognition and BDNF, but no results are provided in the abstract. The design includes multiple phases to assess individual treatment effects over time.
population_specificity: 15 adults with chronic spinal cord injury (>12 months post-injury) above L1 neurological level.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding superimposed NMES to conventional physiotherapy improves quadriceps endurance, strength, functional capacity, and quality of life while reducing dyspnea in older asthma patients.
results_summary: The NMES + PTR group showed significant improvements in quadriceps endurance, strength, functional exercise capacity, and quality of life, along with reduced dyspnea compared to the PTR-only group.
population_specificity: Older patients (age 65+) with mild, persistent, stable asthma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) to therapeutic exercises improved pain and functional disability in women with Patellofemoral Pain (PFP).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between the group receiving NMES plus exercises and the exercise-only group. Both groups showed reduced pain and improved functional disability, but NMES provided no additional benefit.
population_specificity: 34 women with Patellofemoral Pain (mean age 23.8 ± 4.1).
effective_dosage: Not specified (NMES was applied twice a week alongside exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of NMES combined with interrupted serial casting versus serial casting alone on lower limb function in children with diplegic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in ROM and spasticity, but the NMES group demonstrated greater improvements in dorsiflexor strength, knee extensor strength, and gait function.
population_specificity: Children with diplegic cerebral palsy (n=33).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 6 weeks of peroneal longus neuromuscular electrical stimulation improves balance control in young adults with chronic ankle instability.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in balance parameters, including Cumberland Ankle Instability Tool scores, displacement X, root-mean-square, and 95% confidence ellipse area, indicating enhanced static balance control, particularly in the ankle frontal plane.
population_specificity: Young adults with chronic ankle instability

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if neuromuscular electrical stimulation could attenuate adverse effects of hematopoietic stem cell transplantation on physical function, muscle mass, quality of life, and fatigue compared to a sham intervention.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that neuromuscular electrical stimulation will improve physical function, muscle mass, quality of life, and fatigue at short-term follow-up (24±5 days post-transplant) and that pre-transplant physical function will predict long-term (6-month) fatigue and quality of life. Feasibility and acceptability of the intervention during transplantation will also be assessed.
population_specificity: Autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients with hematologic malignancies.
study_duration: Intervention administered until 24±5 days post-transplant (Follow-up 1), with additional assessments at 6 months (Follow-up 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining oral rehabilitation training with neuromuscular electrical stimulation improves pediatric swallowing disorders more effectively than oral rehabilitation training alone.
results_summary: The experimental group receiving combined treatment showed shorter recovery time for normal swallowing function, improved nutritional status, and better quality of life compared to the control group. The study concluded that the combined approach is superior to single-treatment methods.
population_specificity: Children with swallowing disorders meeting the study's inclusion criteria.
